body.p:
Your favor 6th inst reached me a few days since
and having a few moments to spare prior to giving an
audience to some of the great men here, I avail myself
of the happy circumstance to commence with one
whose heart I feel assured beats responsive to the
pulsations of my own.

I verily believe my dear friend that your
penmanship is ever worse than mine, for if you can
decipher my scrawl it is more than I could do with
a considerable portion of your late letter. N' imparte
I would guess at what I could not read and as we usually
commune on subjects of high interest to our Faith, it
was perhaps the more gratifying to trace through the
medium of a few disjointed words, whole sentences &
devotion to the glory of the family of Jacob.

I am fully aware how overtaxed your time must
be, for my part of late I have managed to tear
myself from the awful sedentary & monotonous habits
of an editor, and have indulged myself in some good works
for the credit of our people and the community at large.

I am about to contract for finishing the
inside of our new synagogue and what with Mr Touro
on the one hand with his peculiar notions, and the
mechanics on the other with their attempts to make a
good bargain I assure I am not a little perplexed.
At least on how a day and frequently several hours

do I give to what in a general term may be styled
Judaic affairs. To day I have written to Mr Nathan
pr West India steamer to ascertain on what terms
he would come to us. Mr Touro is favorably impressed
with him. I think we could complete the building
in three months time from now, altho' it may
be longer unless a Hazan can be secured.

I spoke to Mr Touro this morning about
the Paln society, “he was mum!!

Before I forget it let me state that on Friday
last Mr. J P. Benjamin handed me $5.30 for you
I enclose in this a $10 note out of which please pay
yourself that amt & also a small sum which I owe
you for an obituary, the Occident & anything else. I really
do not know if the note I send will cover what I intend
it to, if not be so kind as to advise me in replying
to this letter.

When the Prayer books for Mrs Andrews
reach here I will attend to the matter & remit
you the amount instanter; as it is my habit
now to keep as few accounts as possible. My mind
is kept so constantly on the stretch that I am fearful
of forgetting anything not attended to, & closed at
the same instant.

The subject of an institution of learning
for our youth shall not escape my memory however
& in fact I often allude to it in conversing with Mr
Touro, but he seems to think it best to finish one

Sincerely do I hope to see you one of
these days and to have a good long talk with
you, perhaps when we consecrate our place of
worship one may induce you to pay us a visit
of a few weeks at least. How many things have
transpired “with poor me clear out here” and which
I would like to tell you of. I long to have a dozen
good long talks with you, indeed I do.

And now my good sir let me ask you to
do as I have just done & whenever the chance
offers and your “debts correspondential” are paid
to your other friends, seize the pen & let me
hear of you, how you gig? along, & how the world
uses you. Oblige me & give my fondest love to
my dear little Aunt when you see her, & present
me in becoming terms to Uncle William Mr &
Mrs I L T? & Miss Lar?. By the way you
are held in the very highest esteem by the young lady
The manner in which she spoke of you whilst here
on her recent visit proved to me that her feelings
towards you were precisely like my own & I like her none
the less on that account.

Wishing you the best of health & all other
choice blessings I conclude. Your friend most truly
